articles.headline: Financial Bill to Close Regulator of Fading Industry
articles.snippet: The regulator of savings and loan associations is following the industry, once dominant in mortgages, into oblivion.
articles.abstract: The regulator of savings and loan associations is following the industry, once dominant in mortgages, into oblivion.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Congress creates federal agencies, expands them, sometimes renames or overhauls them. But it almost never gets rid of them. So perhaps the most remarkable piece of the financial regulation bill that Democrats hope to send the president this week is the directive to dismember and close the Office of Thrift Supervision.

articles.headline: Financial Reform Bill Limps Toward Vote
articles.snippet: The legislation meant to address the economic crisis fell victim to partisan bickering.
articles.abstract: The legislation meant to address the economic crisis fell victim to partisan bickering.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  It was supposed to be the one major piece of legislation this year that Republicans and Democrats could see eye to eye on, and vote aye on together in broad numbers. Instead, the sweeping overhaul of the nation’s financial regulatory system, a response to the economic crisis of 2008, will barely squeak through the Senate.

articles.headline: Citing Demand, Intel Tops Forecast
articles.snippet: Revenue rose 34 percent for the chip maker Intel, which posted net income of $2.9 billion.
articles.abstract: Revenue rose 34 percent for the chip maker Intel, which posted net income of $2.9 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: That most elusive object of the workplace during the recent recession-racked years, the new personal computer, is being spotted with increased regularity.

articles.headline: Police Are Charged in Post-Katrina Shootings
articles.snippet: Six officers were charged in connection with shootings on a bridge in the days after Hurricane Katrina.
articles.abstract: Six officers were charged in connection with shootings on a bridge in the days after Hurricane Katrina.
articles.lead_paragraph: NEW ORLEANS  Four current and two former New Orleans police officers have been charged in connection with the killing of unarmed civilians on the Danziger Bridge in the chaotic days after Hurricane Katrina, federal law enforcement officials announced here on Tuesday.

articles.headline: F.C.C. Indecency Policy Rejected on Appeal
articles.snippet: A federal appeals court struck down the Federal Communications Commission’s “fleeting expletives” policy on broadcasts, saying its vagueness could inhibit free speech.
articles.abstract: A federal appeals court struck down the Federal Communications Commission’s “fleeting expletives” policy on broadcasts, saying its vagueness could inhibit free speech.
articles.lead_paragraph: A federal appeals court struck down a Federal Communications Commission policy on indecency Tuesday, saying that regulations barring the use of “fleeting expletives” on radio and television violated the First Amendment because they were vague and could inhibit free speech.

articles.headline: CNN Nears Deal to Fill King’s Slot
articles.snippet: Piers Morgan, the bad-cop judge on “America’s Got Talent,” has told friends the show is his dream job.
articles.abstract: Piers Morgan, the bad-cop judge on “America’s Got Talent,” has told friends the show is his dream job.
articles.lead_paragraph: Piers Morgan, the bad-cop judge on the hit NBC show “America’s Got Talent,” is poised to take over Larry King’s coveted time slot on CNN, a move smoothed by an imminent deal between the two media giants that own the channels, NBC Universal and Turner Broadcasting.
articles.byline: By Brian Stelter and Bill Carter

articles.headline: California May Drop Its Official State Rock
articles.snippet: Geologists oppose legislation that would lift the designation of serpentine — which contains asbestos — as the state rock.
articles.abstract: Geologists oppose legislation that would lift the designation of serpentine — which contains asbestos — as the state rock.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Empirically speaking, geologists are not a particularly irascible group. But those who make their living studying rocks, minerals and gems in California — and increasingly those scientists beyond the state’s borders — are enraged over a bill in Sacramento that would knock serpentine, the official state rock, off its mantel.

articles.headline: Trapped by Gaza Blockade, Locked in Despair
articles.snippet: The three-year blockade by Israel and Egypt — and the bitter rivalry between Palestinian factions — has turned the Gazans’ difficult life into a new torment.
articles.abstract: The three-year blockade by Israel and Egypt — and the bitter rivalry between Palestinian factions — has turned the Gazans’ difficult life into a new torment.
articles.lead_paragraph: GAZA CITY  The women were bleary-eyed, their voices weak, their hands red and calloused. How could they be expected to cook and clean without water or electricity? What could they do in homes that were dark and hot all day? How could they cope with husbands who had not worked for years and children who were angry and aimless?
articles.byline: By Michael Slackman and Ethan Bronner

articles.headline: Afghans to Form Local Forces to Fight Taliban
articles.snippet: After intensive discussions with NATO commanders, the Afghan government approved a program to establish local defense forces around the country.
articles.abstract: After intensive discussions with NATO commanders, the Afghan government approved a program to establish local defense forces around the country.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan  After intensive negotiations with NATO military commanders, the Afghan government on Wednesday approved a program to establish local defense forces that American military officials hope will help remote areas of the country thwart attacks by Taliban insurgents.

articles.headline: Fed Leaders Show Division Over Deflation
articles.snippet: The minutes from the June 22-23 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee cited the threat of deflation for the first time in a year.
articles.abstract: The minutes from the June 22-23 meeting of the Federal Open Market Committee cited the threat of deflation for the first time in a year.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  The Federal Reserve disclosed on Wednesday that its chief policy makers were divided on whether the weak economy faced a new, potentially dangerous threat in the form of deflation.
